case_name: Private limited company v. Income-tax Officer of Porbander

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 39 of 1959 filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 39 of 1959. Appeal by special leave

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated November 26, 1957 of Bombay High Court in Special Civil Application No. 119 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 26, 1957, of the Bombay High Court at Rajkot in Special Civil Application No. 119 of 1956.

facts.text: Appellant is a private limited company carrying on business of manufacturing and selling textiles.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant before us is a private limited companypany carrying on the business of manufacturing and selling textiles and the respondent is the Income-tax Officer of Porbander.

facts.text: Respondent is the Income-tax Officer of Porbander.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant before us is a private limited companypany carrying on the business of manufacturing and selling textiles and the respondent is the Income-tax Officer of Porbander.

facts.text: Previous to the year 1949, no income-tax in Porbander which became part of State of Saurashtra.

anchor.surface_text: Previous to the year 1949, in Porbander which became a part of the State of Saurashtra, there was numberincome-tax.

facts.text: In 1949 Saurashtra Income-tax Ordinance promulgated applicable to State of Saurashtra.

anchor.surface_text: In 1949 the Saurashtra Income-tax Ordinance  hereinafter termed the Ordinance  was promulgated which was applicable to the State of Saurashtra.

facts.text: From 1950 Saurashtra part of Union of India, Indian Income-tax Act applicable by Finance Act of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: By that Ordinance income-tax became leviable and from 1950 onwards when Saurashtra became part of the Union of India the Indian Income-tax Act  hereinafter referred to as the Act  became applicable by reason of the Finance Act of 1950  Act XXV of 1950 .

facts.text: Appellant assessed for accounting year 1949 i.e. assessment year 1950-51, depreciation allowed Rs. 3,43,869 under s.10(2)(vi).

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Was taxed for the accounting year 1949, i.e., the assessment year 1950-51. In that year the amount of depreciation allowed under s. 10 2  vi  of the Act was Rs. 3,43,869.

facts.text: Assessment order for 1953-54 dated June 30, 1955, depreciation allowed Rs. 3,48,105.

anchor.surface_text: According to the assessment order dated June 30, 1965, the amount of depreciation allowed for the assessment year 1953- 54 was Rs. 3,48,105.

facts.text: On August 8, 1955, appellant made application for rectification under s.35 pointing mistakes in depreciation calculations.

anchor.surface_text: On August 8, 1955, the appellant made an application for rectification under s. 35 of the Act. In this application he pointed out several mistakes in calculations in regard to the depreciation amount.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer order dated February 27, 1956 rectifying Written Down Value and determining depreciation Rs. 1,94,074 for 1953-54.

anchor.surface_text: By his order of February 27, 1956, the Income-tax Officer companyrected the Written Down Value of the different properties of the appellant and determined the total allowable depreciation to be Rs. 1,94,074.

facts.text: Unabsorbed depreciation reduced from Rs. 2,31,944 to Rs. 83,295 and set off against 1954-55 income.

anchor.surface_text: And thus the unabsorbed depreciation amount which under the assessment order of June 30, 1955, was Rs. 2,31,944 was reduced to Rs. 83.,295 and this was set off against the appellants income of the assessment year 1954-55.

facts.text: On February 29, 1956, Income-tax Officer passed provisional assessment orders for 1954-55 and 1955-56 using same Written Down Value.

anchor.surface_text: On February 29, 1956, the Income-tax Officer passed two provisional assessment  orders for the years 1954-55 and 1955-56. In both these orders he calculated the depreciation amounts on the basis of the same Written Down Value

facts.text: No written notice of intended rectification given to appellant under s.35 read with s.63.

facts.text: On March 9, 1956, appellant wrote protesting the rectification order.

facts.text: On April 16, 1956, appellant filed petition in Bombay High Court under Arts. 226 and 227.

anchor.surface_text: On April 16, 1956, the appellant filed a petition in the High Court of Bombay under Arts. 226 and 227 in which it alleged that the Income-tax Officer had exceeded the limits of jurisdiction

facts.text: Bombay High Court dismissed petition on November 26, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 26, 1957, of the Bombay High Court at Rajkot in Special Civil Application No. 119 of 1956.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer discussed depreciation figures with appellant's Secretary Shri Ganatra.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court dismissed this petition on the ground that it contained misstatements of fact that The advantage of this jurisdiction is number available to the subject when adequate and efficacious remedy is available to him under the ordinary law

holdings.text: The object of the provision as to notice in s. 35 is that no order should be passed to the detriment of an assessee without affording him an opportunity but it cannot be said that the Rule is so rigid that if, as a matter of fact, the assessee knows of the proceedings and the matter has been discussed with him then an adverse order would be invalid merely because no notice under s. 63 was given. Secondly this provision is applicable only where the assessment is enhanced or refund is reduced. Neither of those contingencies has arisen in the present case.

anchor.surface_text: The object of the provision as to notice in s. 35 is that no order should be passed to the detriment of an assessee without affording him an opportunity but it cannot be said that the Rule is so rigid that if, as a matter of fact, the assessee knows of the proceedings and the matter has been discussed with him then an adverse order would be invalid merely because no notice under s. 63 was given.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assessee informed via discussions with secretary and supplied calculations on 21-2-1956; no enhancement or refund reduction; s.35 notice via s.63 only for those cases; reasonable opportunity given satisfies natural justice.

holdings.text: The record does not mean only the order of assessment but it comprises all proceedings on which the assessment order is based and the Income-tax Officer is entitled for the purpose of exercising his jurisdiction under s. 35 to look into the whole evidence and the law applicable to ascertain whether there was an error.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Record includes prior years' assessments, evidence, rules for verifying WDV calculations; ITO can check previous records.

holdings.text: A mistake contemplated by this section is not one which is to be discovered as a result of an argument but it is open to the Income-tax Officer to examine the record including the evidence and if he discovers any mistake he is entitled to rectify the error provided that if the result is enhancement of assessment or reducing the refund then notice has to be given to the assessee and he should be allowed a reasonable opportunity of being heard.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies precedents (Khem Chand, Venkatachalam); mistake in WDV discoverable by examining prior calculations without debate; qualifies as apparent from record.

holdings.text: Neither the principle of res judicata nor estoppel nor the terms of s. 10(2)(vi) of the Act prevented the Income-tax Officer from determining for himself what the actual cost of the machinery had been and that depreciation had to be calculated for every year and it was open to the Income-tax Officer not merely to perform a mathematical operation on the basis of the Written Down Value of the previous year, but of determining the Written Down Value himself.

anchor.surface_text: It was held that neither the principle of res judicata nor estoppel nor the terms of s. 10 (2) (vi) of the Act prevented the Income-tax Officer from determining for himself what the actual cost of the machinery had been and that depreciation had to be calculated for every year and it was open to the Income-tax Officer not merely to perform a mathematical operation on the basis of the Written Down Value of the previous year, but of determining the Written Down Value himself.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Karnani Industrial Bank: ITO can redetermine actual cost/WDV each year, not bound by prior years; extends to original cost.

holdings.text: Section 35 was open to the Income-tax Officer to rectify mistake apparent from the record in Written Down Value calculations, and s.34 is distinct for escaped income or excessive depreciation.
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.35 for apparent mistakes from record including WDV errors; s.34 for different purpose; supported by scope of s.35 and precedents.

holdings.text: It is not necessary to decide whether the order passed under Art. 226 is of a discretionary nature and therefore in appeal this Court would not interfere with the exercise of discretion, because the case can be decided on other grounds of substance.

anchor.surface_text: It is not necessary to decide in this case whether the order passed under Art. 226 is of a discretionary nature and therefore in appeal this Court would not interfere with the exercise of discretion, because in our opinion, the case can be decided on other grounds of substance.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proceeds to merits instead of procedural bar.

anchor.surface_text: The object of the provision as to notice in s. 35 is that no order should be passed to the detriment of an assessee without affording him an opportunity but it cannot be said that the Rule is so rigid that if, as a matter of fact, the assessee knows of the proceedings and the matter has been discussed with him then an adverse order would be invalid merely because no notice under s. 63 was given.

edges.explanation: The holding directly answers the issue by ruling that the Income-tax Officer was not prevented by res judicata, estoppel, or s. 10(2)(vi) from determining the actual cost.

anchor.surface_text: It was held that neither the principle of res judicata nor estoppel nor the terms of s. 10 (2) (vi) of the Act prevented the Income-tax Officer from determining for himself what the actual cost of the machinery had been and that depreciation had to be calculated for every year and it was open to the Income-tax Officer not merely to perform a mathematical operation on the basis of the Written Down Value of the previous year, but of determining the Written Down Value himself.
dismissing the appellants petition under Art. 226.
